origin: A #|adjective# #|life# #|rarity#ly naturalised in #|habitats#. Its #|part# used as a #|medicinal#. The flowers open in the evening and are visited by a large number of Moth species.
A #|adjective# #|life# found growing on #|habitats#. The #|part# prized in cookery. The #|part# particularly attractive to #|insects#.
A native #|life# #|rarity#ly found in England and Wales, usually on light soils, in open woods, grassland and hedgerows.

A #|rarity# creeping native #|life# of dry grassland and roadside, with bright yellow flowers, often streaks of red. An excellent nector plant and a catapillar food plant for the Common Blue, Dingy Skipper and #|insects#. Height: 10-40cm (4-16in) Perennial: Flowers May to Sept. Contains plant toxins.
A native #|life# with creeping stems, common in #|habitats#.
The #|adjective# white daisy flowers of this #|life# were once a common sight in #|habitats#.  It is now much rarer due to widespread use of selective herbicides.
A #|adjective# #|life# wild flower .  Flowers from June to August.  Prolific in its production of flowers.  Slightly fragrant and can be used as cut flowers.
Seeds itself very prolifically and is related to other campions.
A once common #|life# weed of #|habitats#, now rarely seen.  Bright blue flowers are produced on tall wiry stems with narrow leaves from June to August.  A good butterfly and bee plant.
A tall, widespread, native #|life#, common in #|habitats#. The fluffy white flowers are the earliest flowering of the common hedge bank parsleys.
Cowslips are the food plants of the caterpillars of the Duke of Burgundy Fritillary.

A native #|life# of damp meadows, the flowers appear around the time that cuckoos return in April -May.  The clusters of pink, pale lilac or white flowers attract butterflies and bees.  A caterpillar food plant of the #|insects#.  The #|part# eaten in some regions.

This small #|life# produces brilliant, unscented purple flowers. It can be found in #|habitats# throughout Britain. Its folk-names include 'Blue Mice' and 'Pig Violet'. It is the larval food plant for several species of #|insects#.
A scrambling #|life# commonly found in a wide variety of habitats including #|habitats#.

A spreading native #|life#, which produces long runners, which root at intervals to produce new plants. It produces a white flower and a sweet mini strawberry fruit. It is common in #|habitats# across Britain. It is the larval food plant of the #|insects#.
Yellow flower of #|habitats#. Likes calcareous soils.
Widely used in days gone by to curdle milk for cheese making.
Medicinal, Scent of apricots, Good for bees and insects.
